cb:div.cb:mulu: The Gateless Barrier of the Chan School
cb:div.head: The Gateless Barrier of the Chan School
cb:div.p:
If one says there is no gate, all people on the great earth can enter. If one says there is a gate, there is no share for the Master.
First, forcibly adding a few footnotes is like putting a hat on top of a hat. Insisting on
having Old Xi offer praise is again like squeezing juice from dry bamboo. If such noisy editions are produced, they will not
require Old Xi to make a single throw. With one throw, do not let a single drop fall into rivers and lakes. For a thousand li the black
steed cannot catch up. In the first year of Shaoding, at the end of the seventh month, written by Chen 𡎖 of Xi’an Hermitage.

On the fifth day of the first month of the second year of Shaoding, respectfully encountering the Sacred Festival of Heavenly Foundation, your servant monk
Huikai, earlier on the fifth day of the twelfth month of the first year, printed and circulated forty-eight cases of raising the circumstances of the Buddhas and patriarchs,
praying for the present Emperor’s sacred person to live ten thousand years, ten thousand years,
ten thousand times ten thousand years. Your Majesty the Emperor, I respectfully wish that your sagely brightness equal the sun and moon, and your wise span equal
heaven and earth. In the eight directions they sing of a ruler who possesses the Way; throughout the four seas they rejoice in the transforming power of non-action.

For the merit and recompense of the Compassionate and Virtuous Empresscause of Youci Chan Monastery, former abbot who transmitted the Dharma,
your servant monk Huikai respectfully states

cb:div.cb:mulu: The Gateless Barrier of the Chan School
cb:div.head: The Gateless Barrier of the Chan School
cb:div.p:
The Buddha’s words take mind as the school; no-gate is the Dharma-gate. Since it is no gate, how
does one pass through? Have you not seen it said: what enters by a gate is not the family treasure; what is gained through conditions
begins and ends in success and decay. To speak in this way is very much like raising waves where there is no wind, or cutting good flesh
to make a wound. Moreover, clinging to words and phrases, seeking understanding and interpretation, striking at the moon with a stick,
scratching an itch through a boot—what connection is there? In the summer of the wuzi year of Shaoding, Huikai, while leading the assembly at Dongjia Longxiang,
because students requested instruction, took the ancient masters’ public cases and made them tiles for knocking at the gate,
guiding students according to circumstances. In the end they were copied down and, without realizing it, formed a collection. At first
they were not arranged in order of before and after; together they became forty-eight cases, collectively called The Gateless Barrier.
If there is a fellow who does not care for danger or death, and with a single blade goes straight in, even eight-armed Nezha
cannot hold him back. Even if it be the twenty-eight patriarchs of the West and the six patriarchs of the East, they can only stand watching the wind
and beg for their lives. But if one hesitates, it is like watching a horseman through a window; when you blink your eyes,
it is already missed. The verse says:

lg.l:
The great Way has no gatea thousand differences have roadsif you pass through this barrierheaven and earth
you walk alone

body.byline: Compiled by the studying monk Miyuan Zongshao

cb:div.head: Zhaozhou’s Dog
cb:div.p:
Because a monk asked Master Zhaozhou, “Does a dog have Buddha-nature or not?” Zhou said,
“No.”

Wumen said: To study Chan one must pass through the barrier of the patriarchs. For wondrous awakening one must exhaust the road of the mind
and cut it off. If the patriarchs’ barrier is not passed, and the road of mind is not cut off, one is entirely a spirit clinging to grass and attached to trees.
Now tell me, what is the patriarchs’ barrier? It is just this single word “No.” This
is the one barrier of the Chan school. Therefore it is called The Gateless Barrier of the Chan School. Those who pass through it
not only personally see Zhaozhou, but can also, together with the successive patriarchs, grasp
hands and walk together. Eyebrows entwined together. See with the same eye. Hear with the same ear. Is this not
a joyful celebration? If there is one who wishes to pass through the barrier, then take the three hundred sixty joints
and the eighty-four thousand pores, and throughout the whole body raise up a single mass of doubt. Investigate the single word “No.”
Bring it up day and night. Do not make a nihilistic understanding. Do not make an understanding of being or non-being. It is like swallowing
a red-hot iron ball—you try to vomit it out but cannot. Sweep away all previous evil knowledge
and evil understanding. After a long time it becomes pure and ripe; naturally inside and outside merge into one piece, like
a mute person who has had a dream—he alone knows. Suddenly it bursts forth, astonishing heaven and shaking earth.
It is like seizing General Guan’s great sword in your hand. Meeting a Buddha, you kill the Buddha; meeting a patriarch,
you kill the patriarch. On the brink of birth and death you attain great freedom. Within the six realms and four modes of birth
you roam in samādhi. But how do you bring it up? Exhaust the strength of your whole life.
Raise the single word “No.” If it does not break off, it is like a Dharma candle—once lit, it catches fire.
The verse says:

lg.l: The dog’s Buddha-naturefully brings forth the true commandjust as you touch being or non-being
you lose body and lose life

cb:div.head: Baizhang’s Wild Fox
cb:div.p:
Whenever Master Baizhang was giving instruction, there was an old man who always followed the assembly to listen to the Dharma. When the assembly
withdrew, the old man also withdrew. Suddenly one day he did not withdraw. The master then asked, “Who is it standing before me?”
The old man said, “Yes, I am not a human being. In the past, at the time of Kāśyapa Buddha,
I once lived on this mountain. Because a student asked, ‘Does a greatly practicing person
fall into cause and effect or not?’ I replied, ‘He does not fall into cause and effect.’ For five hundred lifetimes
I fell into the body of a wild fox. Now I ask the Master to turn a phrase on my behalf so that I may
be freed from the wild fox.” Then he asked, “Does a greatly practicing person fall into cause and effect or not?”
The master said, “He is not blind to cause and effect.” At these words the old man had great awakening. He made a bow and said, “I have now been freed from the wild fox
body. I dwell behind the mountain. I dare to inform the Master and request that I be dealt with according to the example of a deceased monk.”
The master ordered the head monk to strike the gavel and inform the assembly that after the meal they would send off a deceased monk. The great assembly discussed it.
All were at ease in the nirvana hall, and no one was ill. Why was it so? After the meal
they only saw the master lead the assembly to the foot of a cliff behind the mountain, where with his staff he picked out a dead wild
fox and then cremated it according to the rite. In the evening the master ascended the hall and brought up the previous story. Huangbo then
asked, “The man of old made a wrong reply by turning a phrase and fell into the body of a wild fox for five hundred lifetimes.
If he does not make a wrong reply, what would it be?” The master said, “Come nearer and I will tell you.”
Huangbo then stepped forward and slapped the master. The master clapped his hands and laughed, saying, “I thought the barbarian’s beard was red,
but there is also a red-bearded barbarian.”

Wumen said: “Not falling into cause and effect”—why then did he fall into a wild fox? “Not blind to cause and effect”—
why then was he freed from the wild fox? If here you are able to place a single eye,
then you will know that the former Baizhang gained the graceful five hundred lifetimes.
The verse says:

lg.l: Not falling, not blindtwo sides, one contestnot blind, not falling
a thousand mistakes, ten thousand mistakes

cb:div.head: Juzhi Raises a Finger
cb:div.p:
Whenever Master Juzhi was questioned, he only raised one finger. Later a boy attendant, because
an outsider asked, “What essential Dharma does the Master teach?” also raised his finger. When Juzhi heard of it,
he took a knife and cut off the boy’s finger. The boy, bearing the pain, ran away crying. Juzhi again called
him. The boy turned his head. Juzhi then raised his finger. The boy suddenly had realization. When Juzhi
was about to pass away, he told the assembly, “I obtained Tianlong’s one-finger Chan. In a lifetime I have used it up
without exhausting it.” Having spoken these words, he manifested extinction.

Wumen said: The place of awakening of Juzhi and the boy was not on the finger. If
you can see here, Tianlong together with Juzhi and the boy
are pierced through on one string with yourself.
The verse says:

lg.l: Juzhi bluntly set down old Tianlongwith a sharp blade he singly tested the little boy
Great Spirit lifts his hand without much effortsplitting Mount Hua into ten thousand layers

cb:div.cb:mulu: The Bearded Man Has No Beard
cb:div.head: The Bearded Man Has No Beard
cb:div.p: Huian said, “The barbarian of the Western Heaven—why does he have no beard?”

Wumen said: Investigation must be genuine investigation; awakening must be genuine awakening. This barbarian
must be personally seen once to be understood. To speak of personally seeing already becomes two.
The verse says:

lg.l: Before a foolone cannot speak of a dreamthe bearded man has no beard
clear awareness only adds confusion

cb:div.head: Xiangyan Up in a Tree
cb:div.p:
Wumen said: Even if you have eloquence like a hanging river, it is entirely of no use. Even if you can expound the entire
Tripiṭaka teachings, it is also of no use. If here you can answer rightly, you bring to life the former dead roadhead,
and kill the former living roadhead. If it is not so,
wait straight until the future and ask Maitreya.
The verse says:

lg.l: Xiangyan truly concocted ithis viciousness has no limit
He silenced the monks’ mouthsand made ghost eyes burst forth over the whole body

cb:div.cb:mulu: The World-Honored One Holds Up a Flower
cb:div.head: The World-Honored One Holds Up a Flower
cb:div.p:
In the past, when the World-Honored One was at the assembly on Vulture Peak, he held up a flower and showed it to the assembly. At that time the assembly all remained silent;
only Venerable Kāśyapa broke into a slight smile. The World-Honored One said: I have the treasury of the true Dharma eye, the wondrous mind of nirvāṇa, the real form, the formless,
the subtle wondrous Dharma gate, not established on文字,
a separate transmission outside the teachings; I entrust it to Mahākāśyapa.

Wumen said: Yellow-faced Gautama acted as if no one were there. He pressed the good down to make it base.
He hung up a sheep’s head and sold dog meat, thinking it was how wonderfully strange. If, at that time, the great
assembly had all laughed, how would the treasury of the true Dharma eye have been transmitted? Suppose Kāśyapa had not
smiled—how would the treasury of the true Dharma eye have been transmitted? If you say the treasury of the true Dharma eye
has transmission and entrustment, the yellow-faced old fellow deceived the townsfolk. If you say there is no transmission,
then why was it granted only to Kāśyapa?
The verse says:

lg.l: When he held up the flowerthe tail was already exposedKāśyapa broke into a smile
humans and gods were at a loss

cb:div.head: Zhaozhou Washes His Bowl
cb:div.p:
Because a monk asked Zhaozhou, “I have just entered the monastery; I beg the Master for instruction.” Zhou said,
“Have you eaten your gruel?” The monk said, “I have eaten my gruel.” Zhou said, “Go wash your bowl.”
That monk had an awakening.

Wumen said: Zhaozhou opened his mouth and showed his gallbladder; he exposed his heart and liver. That monk heard
the matter not truly, and called a bell a jar.
The verse says:

lg.l: Only because it was extremely clearit instead made what was gained come slowly
If you had known early that the lamp is firethe rice has been cooked for a long time

cb:div.head: Xi Zhong Makes a Cart
cb:div.p:
Master Yue’an asked a monk: Xi Zhong made a cart with a hundred spokes. Remove both ends,
take away the axle—what is made clear?

Wumen said: If you can straightaway make it clear, your eyes are like shooting stars, your functioning like a flashing
bolt of lightning.
The verse says:

lg.l: Where the wheel of function turnseven the adept are still deludedthe four quarters above and below
north south east west

cb:div.head: Datong Zhisheng
cb:div.p:
Because a monk asked Master Xingyang Rang: Datong Zhisheng Buddha sat at the place of awakening for ten kalpas;
the Buddha Dharma did not appear before him, and he could not attain Buddhahood—what then? Rang said: That
question is truly fitting. The monk said: Since he sat at the place of awakening, why could he not attain
Buddhahood? Rang said: Because he did not become a Buddha.

Wumen said: Only allow the old barbarian to know; do not allow the old barbarian to understand. If an ordinary person
knows, he is a sage. If a sage understands, he is an ordinary person.
The verse says:

lg.l: Ending the body is not as good as ending the mind and restingwhen the mind is ended, the body has no worry
If body and mind are both completely endedwhy would a transcendent need to be further enfeoffed as a marquis

cb:div.head: Qingshui’s Solitary Poverty
cb:div.p:
Because a monk asked Master Caoshan: “Qingshui is solitary and poor; I beg the Master for relief.” Shan
said, “Tax, ācārya Tax!” Tax responded, “Yes.” Shan said, “Qingyuan’s White-house wine—three cups and
you still say your lips have not been moistened.”

Wumen said: Qingshui yielded the functioning—what mind-action is that? Caoshan had the eye and deeply
discerned the incoming opportunity. Even so, tell me: where is it that ācārya Tax ate
the place of drinking wine.
The verse says:

lg.l: Poor as Fan Danspirit like Xiang Yuthough there is no livelihood
he dares to contend with the rich

cb:div.head: Zhou Examines the Hermit
cb:div.p:
Zhaozhou went to a hermit’s place and asked, “Is there? Is there?” The hermit raised his fist.
Zhou said, “The water is shallow; this is not a place to moor a boat,” and then left. Again he went to another hermit’s place,
saying, “Is there? Is there?” That hermit also raised his fist. Zhou said, “Able to let go, able to seize,
able to kill, able to give life,” and then made a bow.

Wumen said: Both raised a fist alike—why then
did he approve one and not approve one? Tell me, where is the error? If here
you can utter a turning word, you will see Zhaozhou’s tongue has no bone, able to support and able to topple,
attaining great freedom. Even so, how could it be helped that Zhaozhou was nevertheless
seen through by the two hermits? If you say the two hermits have superiority or inferiority, you do not yet have the eye of study. If
you say there is no superiority or inferiority, you also do not yet have the eye of study.
The verse says:

lg.l: Eyes like shooting starsfunction like a lightning flasha knife that kills peoplea sword that gives people life

cb:div.head: Yan Calls the Master
cb:div.p:
Master Ruiyan Yan, every day, would call to himself, “Master,” and then himself would answer, “Yes.” Then
he would say, “Be alert, yes! Another time, another day, do not be deceived by others, yes, yes.”

Wumen said: Old Ruiyan buys and sells himself, producing all these divine
heads and ghost faces. Why𦗚? One that calls, one that answers; one
that is alert, one that is not deceived by others. If you recognize them, it is still not
it. If you imitate him, it is entirely wild-fox understanding.
The verse says:

lg.l: Those who study the Way do not recognize the trueonly because from before they recognized a spirit
The root of birth and death through immeasurable kalpasfools call it the original person

cb:div.head: Deshan Carries His Bowl
cb:div.p:
One day Deshan carried his bowl down from the hall. Seeing Xuefeng, Xuefeng asked, “Old fellow, the bell has not yet
been rung and the drum has not yet sounded—where are you carrying your bowl to?” Deshan then returned to the abbot’s quarters. Xuefeng brought it up
to Yantou. Yantou said, “Great Deshan has not yet understood the last phrase.” Deshan heard of it and ordered the
attendant to call Yantou in. He asked, “You do not approve of this old monk?” Yantou secretly
revealed his meaning. Deshan then let it rest. The next day he ascended the seat, and indeed it was different from usual.
Yantou went before the monks’ hall, clapped his hands, and laughed loudly, saying, “How glad I am the old fellow has understood
the last phrase. Hereafter, people under heaven will have nothing they can do about him.”

Wumen said: As for the last phrase, Yantou and Deshan have both not even dreamed
of it. When you check it out, it is like a shelf of puppets.
The verse says:

lg.l: Recognize the first phrasethen you understand the last phrase
The last and the firstare not this one phrase

cb:div.head: Nanquan Cuts the Cat
cb:div.p:
Master Nanquan, because the east and west halls were arguing over a cat, Nanquan lifted it up and said, “The
assembly, if you can speak, you save it; if you cannot speak, I will cut it.” The assembly had no reply. Nanquan then
cut it. In the evening Zhaozhou returned from outside. Nanquan related it to Zhou. Zhou then took off his sandals and placed them on his
head and went out. Nanquan said, “If you had been here, you would have saved the cat.”

Wumen said: Tell me, what was the meaning of Zhaozhou putting the grass sandals on his head? If here
you can utter a turning word, you will see Nanquan’s command was not carried out in vain. If
it is not so, it is dangerous.
The verse says:

lg.l: If Zhaozhou were therehe would have reversed this commandsnatched away the knife
Nanquan would beg for his life

cb:div.head: Dongshan’s Three Blows
cb:div.p:
Because Yunmen, when Dongshan came to call on him, Yunmen asked, “Where have you just come from?” Dongshan said, “Chadu
ford.” Yunmen said, “Where did you spend the summer?” Dongshan said, “Baozi in Hunan.” Yunmen said, “When did you
leave there?” Dongshan said, “The twenty-fifth day of the eighth month.” Yunmen said, “I spare you three blows.” Dongshan
the next day went up and again asked for instruction: “Yesterday you spared me three blows. I
do not know where my fault was.” Yunmen said, “Rice-bag! Jiangxi, Hunan—you go about like
this!” At this Dongshan had great awakening.

Wumen said: At that time Yunmen gave him his proper fodder, so that Dongshan
had yet another living path; the household gate was not left desolate. All night he was in the sea of
right and wrong, and only at dawn did he arrive. Coming again, he was given another piercing.
Dongshan awakened straightaway; this was not a hurried temperament. Now I ask you all: did Dongshan’s
three blows deserve to be eaten or not? If you say they deserved to be eaten, grasses, trees, and forests
all deserve to be beaten. If you say they did not deserve to be eaten, then Yunmen becomes a liar. If within
this you can make it clear, only then will you breathe out with Dongshan.
The verse says:

lg.l: The lion teaches its cub the trick of the lost onebefore you can even feint and leap, you have already turned over
Without cause he again recounts a head-on strikethe earlier arrow was still light, the later arrow is deep

cb:div.cb:mulu: Seven Strips at the Bell Sound
cb:div.head: Seven Strips at the Bell Sound
cb:div.p: Yunmen said: The world is so vast—why, at the sound of the bell, do you put on seven strips?
The verse says:

lg.l: If you understand, affairs are the same as one householdif you do not understand, ten thousand distinctions and a thousand differences
If you do not understand, affairs are the same as one householdif you understand, ten thousand distinctions and a thousand differences

cb:div.head: The National Teacher’s Three Calls
cb:div.p:
The National Teacher called the attendant three times; the attendant answered three times. The National Teacher said, “I thought I had
failed you; it turns out it is you who have failed me.”

Wumen said: The National Teacher’s three calls—his tongue falls to the ground. The attendant’s three answers—he
harmonizes the light and spits it out. The National Teacher is old and his heart is lonely; he presses the ox’s head to eat grass. The attendant
was unwilling to take it on. Fine food does not satisfy a person who eats in vain. Tell me, where
is the place he failed? When the country is pure, talented sons are valued; when the household is rich, small children are pampered.
The verse says:

lg.l: An iron cangue without a hole makes people carry itit burdens children and grandchildren, not lightly
To be able to brace the gate and prop the doorone must further go barefoot up a mountain of knives

cb:div.head: Dongshan’s Three Pounds
cb:div.p:
Master Dongshan, because a monk asked, “What is Buddha?” Dongshan said, “Three
pounds of hemp.”

Wumen said: Old Dongshan has investigated some clam-and-oyster Chan. Just as he opened the two
shells, he revealed liver and intestines. Even so, tell me: where do you see Dongshan?
The verse says:

lg.l: He thrusts out “three pounds of hemp”the words are intimate and the intent even more intimate
Those who come to speak right and wrongare precisely people of right and wrong

cb:div.head: Ordinary Mind Is the Way
cb:div.p:
Because Nanquan was asked by Zhaozhou, “What is the Way?” Nanquan said, “Ordinary mind is the Way.”
Zhou said, “Can it be aimed toward?” Nanquan said, “If you try to aim toward it, you deviate.”
Zhou said, “If one does not try, how does one know it is the Way?” Nanquan said, “The Way does not belong to knowing; it does not belong to not knowing. Knowing is
deluded awareness; not knowing is indifference. If you truly reach the Way of not trying, it is like great
emptiness, vast and open, utterly unobstructed—how could one forcibly make right and wrong?” At these words Zhaozhou suddenly awakened.

Wumen said: Nanquan, pressed by Zhaozhou’s question, came straight to
tiles disintegrating and ice melting, unable to distinguish and separate. Even if Zhaozhou awakened,
he still had to investigate for thirty more years before he attained it.
The verse says:

lg.l: In spring there are a hundred flowers, in autumn there is the moonin summer there is cool wind, in winter there is snow
If there are no idle matters hanging in the mindthis is a fine season in the human world

cb:div.head: The Man of Great Strength
cb:div.p:
Master Songyuan said: Why is it that the man of great strength cannot lift his foot? He also said:
When he opens his mouth, it is not on the tongue.

Wumen said: Songyuan may be said to
pour out his guts and spill his belly; he only lacks someone to take it up. Even if you take it up straightaway, it is just right to come to Wumen’s place and receive a painful blow.
Why𦗚? To know true gold, look at it in the fire.
The verse says:

lg.l: Lift the foot and trample over the fragrant-water sealower the head and look down upon the four dhyāna heavens
One whole body has nowhere to landplease continue onephrase

cb:div.head: Yunmen’s Dried Dung Stick
cb:div.p: Because a monk asked Yunmen, “What is Buddha?” Yunmen said, “A dried dung stick.”

Wumen said: Yunmen may be said to: the household is poor and it is hard to distinguish plain food; affairs are busy and there is no
time for cursive writing. At a move he brings out a dung stick to brace the gate and prop the door. The flourishing
and decline of the Buddha Dharma can be seen.
The verse says:

lg.l: Lightning flashspark from striking stonein the blink of an eyealready missed

cb:div.head: Kāśyapa’s Flagpole
cb:div.p:
Because Ānanda asked Kāśyapa, “Besides the World-Honored One’s transmission of the gold-brocade robe, what else was separately transmitted?”
Kāśyapa called, “Ānanda.” Ānanda answered, “Yes.” Kāśyapa said, “Knock down the flagpole in front of the gate.”

Wumen said: If here you can utter a turning word, intimately you will see
the assembly on Vulture Peak as if it has not dispersed. If it is not so, Vipāśyin Buddha
early set his mind; up to now he has not attained the wondrous.
The verse says:

lg.l: How is the asking-place compared to the answering-place as intimatehow many people here have sinews grow in their eyes
Elder brother calls, younger brother answers, airing the family shamenot belonging to yin and yang, it is another spring

cb:div.head: Not Thinking Good or Evil
cb:div.p:
Because the Sixth Patriarch was pursued by Senior Monk Ming to Dayu Ridge, the Patriarch, seeing Ming arrive, immediately threw down
the robe and bowl on a rock and said, “This robe is the emblem of faith; can it be contended for by force? Let you take
it.” Ming then lifted it as if it were a mountain, unmoving. Hesitating and trembling, Ming said, “I came
seeking the Dharma, not for the robe. I beg the practitioner to instruct me.” The Patriarch said, “Do not think good, do not
think evil—at just such a time, which is Senior Monk Ming’s original face?” Ming
at once had great awakening. His whole body sweated and flowed; weeping tears, he bowed and asked, “Beyond the previous secret
words and secret meaning, is there further intent?” The Patriarch said, “What I now speak for you
it is not secret. If you turn the light back and look upon your own original face, the secret is right by your
side. Ming said, “Although I was at Huangmei following the assembly, in truth I had not awakened to my own original face.
Now, receiving your pointing out of the place of entry, it is like a person drinking water, knowing for himself whether it is cold or warm. Now you, practitioner,
are indeed my teacher.” The Patriarch said, “If you are like this, then you and I
share the same teacher, Huangmei. Guard and uphold it well.”

Wumen said: The Sixth Patriarch may be said to: when the matter is urgent, the household acts quickly; the old woman’s heart is anxious.
It is like a fresh lychee with the shell peeled off, the pit removed, and placed into your mouth.
He only wants you to swallow it once.
The verse says:

lg.l: It cannot be depicted, it cannot be paintedit cannot be praised, do not accept it as a favor
The original face has nowhere to hidewhen the world collapses, it does not decay

cb:div.head: Apart from Language
cb:div.p:
Master Fengxue—because a monk asked, “Speech and silence involve subtle separation; how can one pass through without violating it?”
Fengxue said, “I always recall, in Jiangnan in the third month, where the partridge cries, a hundred flowers are fragrant.”

Wumen said: Fengxue’s function is like lightning; once he has the road, he goes. Yet how can it help that the person
before him cannot stop his tongue. If here you see it intimately, of yourself there is
a road to emerge. Now, apart from the samādhi of language—bring forth one phrase.
The verse says:

lg.l: Not revealing the phrase of wind and bonebefore speaking, already entrusted
Advancing a step, the mouth mumbles on and onI know you are greatly at a loss

cb:div.head: Preaching from the Third Seat
cb:div.p:
Master Yangshan dreamed he went to Maitreya’s place and sat in the third seat. There was a venerable one
who struck the gavel and said, “Today it is time for the third seat to preach the Dharma.” Yangshan then rose and struck the gavel
and said, “The Mahāyāna Dharma is apart from the four propositions and cuts off the hundred negations. Listen attentively, listen attentively.”

Wumen said: Tell me—was it preaching the Dharma or not preaching the Dharma? Open the mouth and you lose; close
the mouth and you also lose. Not opening and not closing—one hundred and eight thousand.
The verse says:

lg.l: Bright day, blue skyin a dream, speaking a dreampinch the strange, pinch the strange
deceiving the whole assembly

cb:div.cb:mulu: Two Monks Roll Up the Blind
cb:div.head: Two Monks Roll Up the Blind
cb:div.p:
Qingliang, the Great Dharma Eye—because, before the meal, a monk came up for interview. The Eye pointed with his hand to the blind. At that time
two monks together went and rolled up the blind. The Eye said, “One gains, one loses.”

Wumen said: Tell me—who gained and who lost? If here you place
one eye, you will know where National Teacher Qingliang fell short. Yet even so,
strictly avoid deliberating within gain and loss.
The verse says:

lg.l: Rolled up, clearly it penetrates the great voidyet the great void still does not accord with my school
Why not put it all down from emptinessdense and fine, not letting wind pass through

cb:div.head: Not Mind, Not Buddha
cb:div.p:
Master Nanquan—because a monk asked, “Is there a Dharma that you do not speak to people?”
Nanquan said, “There is.” The monk said, “What is the Dharma you do not speak to people?” Nanquan said, “Not
mind, not Buddha, not a thing.”

Wumen said: Nanquan, by this one question, was driven to probe to the end all his household goods—he had
not little on hand.
The verse says:

lg.l: Repeated admonitions diminish your virtuewordlessness truly has merit
Let the blue sea change as it willin the end I will not make it pass through for you

cb:div.head: Long Echo at Longtan
cb:div.p:
Because Longtan was consulted by Deshan into the night, Longtan said, “The night is deep—why do you not go down?”
Deshan then, with thanks, lifted the blind and went out. Seeing it was dark outside, he returned and said, “It is dark
outside.” Longtan then lit a paper candle and handed it over. As Deshan was about to take it, Longtan blew it out. Deshan
hereupon suddenly had insight, and bowed. Longtan said, “What principle have you seen?”
Deshan said, “From today onward, I will not doubt the tongues of the old monks under heaven.”
The next day Longtan ascended the hall and said, “Among you there is a fellow whose fangs are like
sword-trees, whose mouth is like a basin of blood; a single blow cannot make him turn back. Another time, another day, atop
a lone peak he will establish my Way there.” Deshan then took his commentarial notes; before the Dharma hall
he set a torch. Lifting them up he said, “To exhaust all subtle discriminations is like a single hair sent into the great
void; to drain all the pivot of the world is like a single drop cast into a vast ravine.” Then he burned the notes.
Thus he bowed and took leave.

Wumen said: Before Deshan passed the barrier, his mind was indignant and his mouth full of protest. He
came to the south, intending to wipe out the meaning of a separate transmission outside the teachings. When he reached
the road in Lizhou, he asked an old woman to buy refreshments. The old woman said, “Great Virtuous One, in your cart
what writings are these?” Deshan said, “Diamond Sūtra commentarial notes.” The old woman said, “Just as
the sūtra says: the past mind cannot be grasped, the present mind cannot be grasped, the future mind cannot be grasped. Great Virtuous One,
which mind do you want to refresh?” Deshan, by this
one question, was left with a mouth like the eaves of a board. Yet even so, he would not die under the old
woman’s phrase. So he asked the old woman, “Nearby, what Chan master is there?”
The old woman said, “Five li away is Master Longtan.” When he reached Longtan, he swallowed up all his
failings; it may be said his earlier words did not match his later words. Longtan was very much like one who pities
a child and does not notice ugliness: seeing he had a little fire-seed, he hurriedly poured foul water,
and all at once doused it, dousing it dead. Coldly looked at, it is a fine laugh.
The verse says:

lg.l: Hearing the name is not as good as seeing the faceseeing the face is not as good as hearing the name
Although it saves the nostrilshow can it help that it blinds the eyes

cb:div.head: Not Wind, Not Banner
cb:div.p:
Because the Sixth Patriarch, when the wind tossed the monastery banner, two monks debated. One said, “The banner moves.” One
said, “The wind moves.” Back and forth, they never accorded with principle. The Patriarch said, “It is not the wind that moves, it is not
the banner that moves; benevolent ones, it is your mind that moves.” The two monks were startled.

Wumen said: Not the wind moves, not the banner moves, not the mind moves—where
do you see the patriarch? If here you see it intimately, only then will you know the two monks
bought iron and got gold; the patriarch, unable to suppress a smile, let slip a leak.
The verse says:

lg.l: Wind, banner, mind movingall alike are taken in one handonly knowing to open the mouth
not realizing words fall through

cb:div.head: Mind Itself Is Buddha
cb:div.p: Because Mazu was asked by Damei, “What is Buddha?” The Patriarch said, “Mind itself is Buddha.”

Wumen said: If you can straightaway grasp it, you wear Buddha’s robe and eat Buddha’s
eat Buddha’s food. Speak Buddha’s words and act Buddha’s actions. That is Buddha. Even so, Damei has led many people
to mistakenly take the fixed north star for certain. How could they know that saying the word “Buddha”
requires rinsing one’s mouth for three days. If he were a true man, on hearing “mind itself is Buddha,” he would cover
his ears and run.
The verse says:

lg.l: Blue sky, bright daystrictly avoid seekingto ask again “how?”
is to hug stolen goods and cry injustice

cb:div.head: Zhaozhou Tests the Old Woman
cb:div.p:
Because Zhaozhou asked an old woman, “Which way does the road to Mount Tai go?” The old woman said, “Go straight
on.” When the monk had gone three or five steps, the old woman said, “A fine monk—he goes off like that too.”
Later a monk reported this to Zhaozhou. Zhaozhou said, “Wait—I’ll go test that
old woman for you.” The next day he went and asked in the same way. The old woman answered in the same way. Zhaozhou returned
and said to the assembly, “I have tested through that Mount Tai old woman for you.”

Wumen said: The old woman only knew how to sit and plan within the curtains; yet she put her mark on the thief, not
knowing that old man Zhaozhou was skilled at using the tactic of raiding the camp and seizing the fortress. And furthermore he has no
great-man’s marks. Examining it, both have fault. Tell me—where is it
that Zhaozhou tested through the old woman?
The verse says:

lg.l: The question is the samethe answer is also similarsand in the rice
thorns in the mud

cb:div.head: An Outsider Asks the Buddha
cb:div.p:
Because the World-Honored One was asked by an outsider, “I do not ask with words; I do not ask without words.” The World-Honored One sat
on his seat. The outsider praised him, saying, “The World-Honored One’s great kindness and great compassion have opened my cloud of delusion and enabled
me to enter.” Then he made full bows and departed. Ānanda then asked the Buddha, “What has the outsider
realized, that he praised you and departed?” The World-Honored One said, “Like a fine horse of the world that moves
when it sees the shadow of the whip.”

Wumen said: Ānanda is a disciple of the Buddha, yet he is not as good as the outsider’s understanding.
Tell me—how far apart are the outsider and the Buddha’s disciple?
The verse says:

lg.l: Walking on a sword’s edgerunning on ice ridgesnot treading steps
over a clifflet go

cb:div.head: Not Mind, Not Buddha
cb:div.p: Because a monk asked Mazu, “What is Buddha?” The Patriarch said, “Not mind, not Buddha.”
Wumen said: If you see it here, your matter of practice is finished.
The verse says:

lg.l: When you meet a swordsman on the road, you must presentif you do not meet a poet, do not offer
When you meet people, speak only three partsyou cannot bestow the whole in one piece

cb:div.head: Wisdom Is Not the Way
cb:div.p: Nanquan said, “Mind is not Buddha; wisdom is not the Way.”

Wumen said: Nanquan may be said to be old and without shame. As soon as he opened his stinking mouth, the household
shame was broadcast outside. Even so, those who know gratitude are few.
The verse says:

lg.l: When the sky is clear, the sun comes outwhen rain falls, the ground becomes wet
I have said it all entirelyI only fear you will not be able to believe it

cb:div.head: Qiannü’s Soul Leaves the Body
cb:div.p: The Fifth Patriarch asked a monk, “When Qiannü’s soul left the body, which one was the real one?”

Wumen said: If here you awaken to what is real, then you will know leaving the shell and entering
the shell is like lodging at an inn. If it is not so, do not run about in confusion. Suddenly when
earth, water, fire, and wind disperse, you will be like a crab dropped into boiling water, seven hands and eight feet. At that time
do not say you were not told.
The verse says:

lg.l: Clouds and moon are the samestreams and mountains each differten thousand blessings, ten thousand blessings
is it one, is it two

cb:div.cb:mulu: Meeting the Adept on the Road
cb:div.head: Meeting the Adept on the Road
cb:div.p:
The Fifth Patriarch said, “When you meet an adept on the road, do not respond with speech or silence. Tell me—what
will you respond with?”

Wumen said: If here you respond intimately, it is no harm to rejoice. If
it is not so, you must also place your eyes everywhere.
The verse says:

lg.l: Meeting an adept on the roaddo not respond with speech or silence
A fist splitting the cheeks, striking you in the faceif you understand straightaway, you understand

cb:div.head: Cypress Tree in the Courtyard
cb:div.p:
Because a monk asked Zhaozhou, “What is the meaning of the patriarch’s coming from the west?” Zhaozhou said, “The
cypress tree in the courtyard.”

Wumen said: If at Zhaozhou’s answer you see it intimately, before there is no Śākyamuni,
after there is no Maitreya.
The verse says:

lg.l: Words do not reveal the matterspeech does not hit the opportunitythose who take up the words lose
those who cling to phrases are deluded

cb:div.cb:mulu: An Ox Passing Through a Window Lattice
cb:div.head: An Ox Passing Through a Window Lattice
cb:div.p:
The Fifth Patriarch said, “It is like a water-buffalo passing through a window lattice. Head, horns, and four hooves have all passed
through. Why is it that the tail cannot pass through?”

Wumen said: If here you turn things upside down and plant one eye, and bring forth
a turning phrase, you can above repay the four恩 and below aid the three realms of existence. If it is not
so, you must further take care of the tail to the end.
The verse says:

lg.l: Going past, you fall into a pit and trenchcoming back, you are again ruined
This little tailtruly is most strange

cb:div.head: Yunmen’s Words Fall Through
cb:div.p:
Because a monk asked Yunmen, “Radiant quiescent illumination pervades like the sands of the river. In one phrase unceasing—” Yunmen
abruptly said, “Isn’t that the words of the scholar Zhang Zhuo?” The monk said, “It is.” Yunmen said, “Your words fall through.”
Later Sixing picked it up and said, “Tell me—where is it that this monk’s words fell through?”

Wumen said: If here you see Yunmen’s use, that monk in solitary peril—
why did his words fall through? He is fit to be teacher of humans and devas. If you do not understand,
you cannot save yourself.
The verse says:

lg.l: Fishing in a swift currentthe greedy-for-bait get caughtas soon as the mouth seam opens
Life and fate are lost

cb:div.cb:mulu: Weishan Kicks Over the Purifying Vase
cb:div.head: Weishan Kicks Over the Purifying Vase
cb:div.p:
Weishan, while he was first in Baizhang’s assembly, served as head cook. Baizhang was about to choose
the master of Great Weishan, and asked the head seat, together with him, to speak before
the assembly: whoever went beyond the pattern could go. Baizhang then lifted up a purifying vase,
set it on the ground, and posed the question, saying, “You must not call it a purifying vase. What do you call it?” The head seat then said, “It cannot be called a wooden 𣔻.”
Then Baizhang asked Weishan. Weishan kicked over the purifying vase and left. Baizhang
laughed and said, “The first seat has been outdone by Weishan.” So he appointed him as the founding abbot.

Wumen said: For one bout Weishan showed courage, yet he still could not leap out
of Baizhang’s enclosure. Examining it, it is heavy, not light. Why𦗚? Having taken off
the headband, he shoulders an iron cangue.
The verse says:

lg.l: He tossed down the bamboo basket and wooden ladlein broad daylight one thrust cuts off all roundaboutness
Baizhang’s heavy barrier could not hold him backwith the tip of his foot he kicks out Buddhas like hemp

cb:div.head: Bodhidharma Pacifies the Mind
cb:div.p:
Bodhidharma faced the wall. The Second Patriarch stood in the snow and cut off his arm, saying, “This disciple’s mind is not at peace. I beg you,
Master, pacify my mind.” Bodhidharma said, “Bring me your mind, and I will pacify it for you.” The Patriarch said, “Seeking the mind,
it cannot be found.” Bodhidharma said, “I have pacified your mind for you.”

Wumen said: The tooth-gapped old barbarian sailed ten thousand miles across the sea, coming on purpose.
It may be said he raised waves where there was no wind. In the end he took in a single disciple,
yet even he lacked the six faculties. Eh—Xie Sanlang did not recognize four characters.
The verse says:

lg.l: Directly pointing from the Westthe affair arose from an entrustingstirring up the monasteries
it turns out it was you

cb:div.head: A Woman Emerges from Samādhi
cb:div.p:
In the past, the World-Honored One, because Mañjuśrī came to the place where the Buddhas assembled, encountered that the Buddhas had each returned to their original
places. Only one woman remained, sitting close to that Buddha and entered into samādhi. Mañjuśrī then
addressed the Buddha: how is it that this woman can sit close to the Buddha, while I cannot? The Buddha told Mañjuśrī,
“You only need to awaken this woman and make her rise from samādhi; then you may question her yourself.” Mañjuśrī
circled the woman three times, snapped his fingers once, and then carried her up to the Brahmā Heaven. Exhausting his spiritual
power, he still could not bring her out. The World-Honored One said, “Even if a hundred thousand Mañjuśrīs were here, they still could not bring this
woman out of samādhi. Below, beyond twelve hundred million Ganges-sands of buddha-lands, there is
the bodhisattva Wàngmíng. He can bring this woman out of samādhi.” In an instant the great being Wàngmíng emerged from
the earth, bowed to the World-Honored One, and the World-Honored One commanded Wàngmíng to go back to the woman.
He snapped his fingers once, and the woman thereupon emerged from samādhi.

Wumen said: Old Śākyamuni staged this mixed drama—quite
unskilled. Tell me: Mañjuśrī is teacher of the seven Buddhas—why could he not bring the woman out of samādhi?
Wàngmíng is a first-ground bodhisattva—why could he bring her out? If within this
you see it intimately, karmic consciousness busily rushing is the great samādhi of the nāga.
The verse says:

lg.l: Whether one can bring her out or cannotshe herself attains freedom
Spirit heads and ghost facesruined gaps are truly elegant

cb:div.head: Shoushan’s Bamboo Stick
cb:div.p:
Shoushan, lifting up a bamboo stick, showed it to the assembly and said, “If you people call it
a bamboo stick, you touch it. If you do not call it a bamboo stick, you turn your back on it. You all, tell me: what do you
call it?”

Wumen said: Call it a bamboo stick and you touch it; do not call it a bamboo stick and you turn your back on it.
You must not have words; you must not have no words. Speak quickly, speak quickly.
The verse says:

lg.l: He lifts up the bamboo stickand carries out the command of killing and giving lifebacking and touching gallop together
Buddhas and patriarchs beg for their lives

cb:div.head: Bajiao’s Staff
cb:div.p:
Bajiao showed the assembly and said, “If you have a staff, I give you a staff.
If you do not have a staff, I take away your staff.”

Wumen said: Supporting you across the broken bridge’s water, accompanying you back to the moonless village. If you call it
a staff, you enter hell like an arrow.
The verse says:

lg.l: The deep and the shallow of all quartersare all within the grasp of the palm
Propping up heaven and supporting eartheverywhere it stirs the school’s wind

cb:div.head: Who Is He?
cb:div.p:
Master Dongshan Yan said, “Śākyamuni and Maitreya are still his slaves. Tell me—who
is he?”

Wumen said: If you see him clearly, it is like meeting your own father
at a crossroads. You no longer need to ask anyone else
whether it is or is not.
The verse says:

lg.l: Do not draw his bowdo not ride his horsedo not argue his right and wrong
do not know his affairs

cb:div.cb:mulu: Advancing from the Tip of a Pole
cb:div.head: Advancing from the Tip of a Pole
cb:div.p:
Shishuang said, “How do you advance from the tip of a hundred-foot pole?” And an ancient worthy said,
“A person who sits at the top of a hundred-foot pole—though he has entered, it is not yet true. At the top of a hundred-foot pole
you must advance a step, and the ten directions’ world manifests the full body.”

Wumen said: Advance a step and turn over the body—what place is there that is not worthy of reverence?
Even so, tell me: how do you advance from the tip of a hundred-foot pole? Hah.
The verse says:

lg.l: Blind the eye at the crown of the gatemistakenly take the fixed north star
𢬵Body able to cast away lifeone blind man leads a crowd of blind men

cb:div.head: Tuṣita’s Three Barriers
cb:div.p:
Master Tuṣita Yue set up three barriers to question students: brushing aside grass to investigate the mysterious only
seeks to see one’s nature—right now, where is the venerable one’s nature? Recognize your own nature, and only then
escape birth and death—when the light of the eyes falls, how do you escape? Escape birth and death, and then
you know where you go—when the four elements separate, where do you go?

Wumen said: If you can bring forth these three turning phrases, then you can, wherever you are,
be the master; encountering conditions, you are the school. If it is not so, coarse food is easily filling; fine chewing
is hard to stave off hunger.
The verse says:

lg.l: In one thought, universally contemplate immeasurable kalpasthe affairs of immeasurable kalpas are just now
Now, see through this single thoughtsee through the person who sees through the now

cb:div.head: Qianfeng’s One Road
cb:div.p:
Master Qianfeng, because a monk asked, “The Bhagavāns of the ten directions, one road—the gate of nirvāṇa.
I wonder, where is the road’s entrance?” Feng picked up his staff, drew a line and said,
“It’s here.” Later a monk went to inquire of Yunmen. Men picked up a fan and said, “The fan
𨁝leaps and jumps, up to the Thirty-Three Heavens, and rams into Indra’s nostrils; an East Sea carp
is struck with one blow, and rain pours as if a basin were overturned.”

Wumen said: One person, down at the deep sea’s bottom,
sifts earth and raises dust; one person, atop a very high mountain,
sets white waves surging to the sky. Holding fast and letting go, each puts out a single hand to uphold the school’s vehicle—just like two camels crashing
into each other. In the world there should be no straightforward person. With the true eye observing,
these two great elders have never recognized where the road’s entrance is.
The verse says:

lg.l: Before lifting a foot, you have already arrivedbefore moving the tongue, you have already spoken
Even if, in every move, you’re ahead of the mechanismyou still must know there is an upward key

cb:div.p:
From above, the Buddhas and Patriarchs have handed down pivotal occasions; they cite the charge and close the case—there were originally no extra words.
Flip off the skullcap and reveal the eyes; they are willing that people accept directly,
not seeking from others. If you are a universally capable superior person, as soon as you hear it raised, you immediately know
where it lands. There is no gate to enter, and no ranks to ascend. Swinging your arms,
you pass the barrier, not asking the barrier guard. Have you not seen Xuansha say: the gate of liberation has no gate,
the intention of the person of no-intention is no intention. And Baiyun said: clearly you know the Way,
yet it’s just this—why can’t you get through? Speaking like this too
is red earth smearing cow’s milk. If you get through the Gateless Barrier, you have already foolishly set Wumen
aside; if you cannot get through the Gateless Barrier, then you also betray yourself. What is called:
the nirvāṇa mind is easy to understand; discriminating wisdom is hard to clarify. Clarify discriminating wisdom, and home
and country will naturally be at peace. At the time, five days before the release from summer retreat in the first year of Shaoding’s reign change, Yangqi’s
eighth-generation grandson, the bhikṣu Wumen Huikai, respectfully recorded.

cb:juan.cb:jhead: End of the Gateless Barrier scroll

lg.l:
Follow rules and keep to measures。Without rope, bind yourself。Unhindered in all directions。The outsiders’ demon army。Maintain
心澄寂。

默照邪禪。恣意忘緣。墮落深坑。惺
惺不昧。

帶鎖擔枷。思善思惡。地獄天堂。佛
見法見。

二銕圍山。念起即覺。弄精魂漢。兀
然習定。

鬼家活計。進則迷理。退則乖宗。不
進不退。

有氣死人。且道如何履踐。努力今
生須了却。
莫教永劫受餘殃。

我手何似佛手。摸得枕頭背後。不覺大笑呵
呵。
元來通身是手。

我脚何似驢脚。未舉步時踏著。一任四海橫
行。
倒跨楊岐三脚。

人人有箇生緣。各各透徹機先。那吒折骨還
父。
五祖豈藉爺緣。

佛手驢脚生緣。非佛非道非禪。莫怪無門關
險。
結盡衲子深冤。
瑞巖近日有無門掇向繩床判古今
凡聖路頭俱截斷幾多蟠蟄起雷音

cb:div.p: 請

無門首座。立僧山偈奉謝。紹定庚寅季春
無量宗壽書。

達磨西來。不執文字。直指人心。見性成佛。說
箇直指。已是迂曲。更言成佛。郎當不少。既是
無門。因甚有關。老婆心切惡聲流布。無庵欲
贅。一語又成四十九則。其間些子誵訛。剔起
眉毛薦取。淳祐乙巳夏重刊。

檢校少保寧武軍節度使京湖安撫制置大使
兼屯田大使兼蘷路策應大使兼知江陵府漢
東郡開國公食邑二千一百戶食實封陸佰戶
孟珙 跋

無門老禪。作四十八則語。判斷古德公案。大
似賣油餅。人令買家開口接了更吞吐不得。
然雖如是。安晚欲就渠熱爐熬上。再打一枚
足成大衍之數。却仍前送似。未知。

老師從何處下牙。如一口喫得。放光動地。若
猶未。也連見在四十八箇。都成熱沙去。速道
速道。

cb:div.head: 第四十九則語
cb:div.p:
經云。止止不須說我法妙難思。安晚曰。法從
何來。妙從何有。說時又作麼生。豈但豐干饒
舌。元是釋迦多口。這老子造作妖怪。令千百
代兒孫被葛藤纏倒。未得頭出。似這般奇特
話靶。匙挑不上。甑蒸不熟。有多少錯認底。傍
人問云。畢竟作如何結斷。安晚合十指爪曰。
止止不須說我法妙難思。却急去難思兩字
上。打箇小圓相子。指示眾人。大藏五千卷。維
摩不二門。總在裏許。
頌曰。

lg.l: 語火是燈掉頭弗譍惟賊識賊
一問即承

cb:div.p:
淳祐丙午季夏初吉安晚居士書于西湖漁
莊

舊板磨滅故。重命工鋟梓畢。這板置于武
藏州兜率山廣園禪寺也。
應永乙酉十月十三日 幹緣比丘 常牧
